titleStmt.title: Multiperson decision making with different preference representation structures: A direct consensus framework and its properties

analytic.title: Multiperson decision making with different preference representation structures: A direct consensus framework and its properties

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Multiperson decision making Consensus Preference representation structures Social choice theory Internal consistency

div.p: This study proposes a direct consensus framework for multiperson decision making (MPDM) with different preference representation structures (preference orderings, utility functions, multiplicative preference relations and fuzzy preference relations). In this framework, the individual selection methods, associated with different preference representation structures, are used to obtain individual preference vectors of alternatives. Then, the standardized individual preference vectors are aggregated into a collective preference vector. Finally, based on the collective preference vector, the feedback adjustment rules, associated with different preference representation structures, are presented to help the decision makers reach consensus. This study shows that the proposed framework satisfies two desirable properties: (i) the proposed framework can avoid internal inconsistency issue when using the transformation functions among different preference representation structures; (ii) it satisfies the Pareto principle of social choice theory. The results in this study are helpful to complete Chiclana et al.'s MPDM with different preference representation structures.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In multiperson decision making (MPDM) problems, it is quite natural that different decision makers may have different experience, cultures and educational backgrounds. As a result, these decision makers may use different preference representation structures to express their individual preference information.

Chiclana et al. [6] initiated a notable MPDM model based on fuzzy preference relations, where the preference information can be represented by means of preference orderings, utility functions and fuzzy preference relations. Chiclana et al. [7] further incorporated multiplicative preference relations in the MPDM model. Herrera et al. [22] proposed a multiplicative MPDM model involving three kinds of preference representation structures (preference orderings, utility functions, multiplicative preference relations), assuming the multiplicative preference relations as the uniform element of the preference representation structures. Dong et al. [16] presented a linguistic MPDM model based on linguistic preference relations, integrating fuzzy preference relations, different types of multiplicative preference relations and multigranular linguistic preference relations. Moreover, Herrera et al. [23], Herrera and Mart√≠nez [26], Herrera-Viedma et al. [31], Mata et al. [35], Chen and Ben-Arieh [5] and Jiang et al. [32] introduced several methods to solve the MPDM problems with multi-granularity linguistic evaluation information. In [30], Herrera-Viedma et al. proposed a consensus model for the MPDM problem with different preference representation structures. Palomares et al. [39] proposed an attitude-driven web consensus support system for heterogeneous group decision making.

Several desirable properties have been proposed in the MPDM model with different preference representation structures. Chiclana et al. [9] and Dong et al. [13] discussed the conditions under which the reciprocity property is maintained in the aggregation of fuzzy preference relations using the ordered weighted average (OWA) operator [46] guided by a relative linguistic quantifier [47]. Meanwhile, in the above MPDM models, the internal consistency is a key issue. The internal consistency refers to the ranking among alternatives derived from the transformed preference representation structure is the same one from the original preference representation structure. Chiclana et al. [7,8] and Dong et al. [16] studied the conditions under which the internal consistency is maintained.

Inspired by the MPDM model initiated by Chiclana et al. [6] and the corresponding consensus model presented in Herrera-Viedma et al. [30], and also inspired by the direct approach presented in Herrera et al. [25], this study proposes a direct consensus framework for MPDM problems with different preference representation structures (preference orderings, utility functions, multiplicative preference relations and fuzzy preference relations). In the direct consensus framework, the individual selection methods, associated with different preference representation structures, are used to obtain individual preference vectors of alternatives. Then, the standardized individual preference vectors are aggregated into a collective preference vector. Finally, based on the collective preference vector, the feedback adjustment rules, associated with different preference representation structures, are presented to help the decision makers reach consensus. The results in this study are helpful to complete Chiclana et al.'s MPDM with different preference representation structures, based on the following reasons:

(i) The proposed framework can avoid internal inconsistency issue when using the transformation functions among different preference representation structures. (ii) It satisfies the Pareto principle of social choice theory.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the preliminary knowledge regarding four kinds of preference representation structures (preference orderings, utility functions, multiplicative preference relations and fuzzy preference relations) and the OWA operator. A direct consensus framework for MPDM problems with different preference representation structures is proposed, and the differences between our proposal and models presented in [6,7,30] are analyzed in Section 3. Following this, the selection process is designed in Section 4. Subsequently, Section 5 proposes the consensus processes to help the decision makers reach consensus. Two desirable properties are presented in Section 6, and an illustrative example is provided in Section 7. Finally, concluding remarks are included in Section 8.

div.head: Preliminaries: Four kinds of preference representation structures and OWA operator
div.p: This section introduces four kinds of preference representation structures and the OWA operator.

div.head: Preference representation structures
div.p: Let X = {x 1 , x 2 , . . ., x n }(n P 2) be a finite set of alternatives. These alternatives have to be classified from best to the worst, according to the preference information provided by a set of decision makers, E = {e 1 , e 2 , . . ., e m } (m P 2).
This study assumes that the decision makers' preference information over the set of alternatives X may be represented in one of the following four formats (see Definitions 1-4).

div.head: Definition 1 (Preference orderings [43]). A vector
div.formula: O = (o 1 , o 2 , . . ., o n ) T is called a preference ordering, where o i o i ¬º 1; 2; . . . ; n √∞ √û denotes the positional order of alternative x i in X = {x 1 , x 2 , . . ., x n }.
div.p: Definition 2 (Utility functions [44]). A vector U = (u 1 , u 2 , . . ., u n ) T is called a utility function, where u i 2 [0, 1] represents the utility evaluation value given by a decision maker to the alternative x i . Definition 3 (Multiplicative preference relations [41]). A matrix A = (a ij ) n√Çn is called a multiplicative preference relation if a ij √Ç a ji = 1 and a ij > 0 for "i, j, where a ij indicates a ratio of the preference intensity of alternative x i to that of x j . Definition 4 (Fuzzy preference relations [37,44]). A fuzzy preference relation on a set of alternatives X is represented by a matrix P = (p ij ) n√Çn , where p ij 2 [0, 1] denotes the preference degree of the alternative x i over x j . A fuzzy preference relation usually assumed to be additive reciprocal, i.e., p ij + p ji = 1, "i, j.

div.head: OWA operator
div.p: Let {a 1 , a 2 , . . ., a l } be a set of values to aggregate. The OWA operator is defined as [46] OWA√∞a 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ;
div.formula: a l √û ¬º X l k¬º1 k k b k :√∞1√û
div.p: where b k is the k th largest value in {a 1 , a 2 , . . ., a l }, and k = (k 1 , k 2 , . . ., k l ) T is an associated weight vector, such that k i 2 [0, 1] and

In [47], Yager suggested an effective method to compute k = (k 1 , k 2 , . . ., k l ) T using linguistic quantifiers, which, in the case of a nondecreasing proportional quantifier Q, is given by this expression:
Q(r) can be represented as [48]:
div.formula: Q √∞r√û ¬º 0; r < a; r√Äa b√Äa ; a 6 r 6 b; 1; r > b; 8 > < > :√∞3√û
div.p: There are several common relative linguistic quantifiers, such as all, most, at least half and as many as possible, where the parameters (a, b) are (0, 1), (0.3, 0.8), (0, 0.5) and (0.5, 1), respectively. When a fuzzy linguistic quantifier Q is used to compute the weights of the OWA operator, it is symbolized by OWA Q .

div.head: Proposed framework
div.p: This section proposes a direct consensus framework for the MPDM with different preference representation structures. And the differences between our proposal and the models presented in Chiclana et al. [6,7] and Herrera-Viedma et al. [30] are also analyzed.

div.head: Direct consensus framework
div.p: Let X and E be as earlier. Let E U , E O , E A and E P be four subsets of E, representing decision makers whose preference information on X are expressed by utility functions, preference orderings, multiplicative preference relations, and fuzzy preference relations, respectively. Without loss of generality, this study assumes that E U ¬ºfe 1 ; e 2 ; . . . ; e m 1 g; E O ¬ºfe m 1 √æ1 ; e m 1 √æ2 ; . . . ; e m 2 g; E A ¬º fe m 2 √æ1 ; e m 2 √æ2 ;
. . . ; e m 3 g and E P ¬º fe m 3 √æ1 ; e m 3 √æ2 ; . . . ; e m g.

In MPDM models (e.g., [24,27,30]), there are two processes to implement before obtain a final solution, namely: (1) the selection process; and (2) the consensus process. Inspired by these two processes, we proposed a direct framework for MPDM problems with four kinds of preference representation structures. This direct framework is presented in Fig. 1. In this framework, the selection process and the consensus process are used.
(1) Selection process.

In this process, we obtain the standardized individual preference vectors and the standardized collective preference vector. The implementation of this selection process deals with a two-step procedure.

(i) Obtaining individual preference vectors. In this step, the individual selection methods, associated with different preference representation structures, are used to obtain individual preference vectors. (ii) Obtaining a collective preference vector.
In this step, the individual preference vectors are transformed into standardized individual preference vectors.

Then, a collective preference vector is obtained from the standardized individual preference vectors, using an OWA operator. Finally, the collective preference vector is transformed into the standardized collective preference vector.
The details of the selection process are introduced in Section 4. (2) Consensus process.

The aim of the consensus process is to improve the consensus level among the decision makers. The implementation of this consensus process deals with a two-step procedure. (i) Consensus measure. In this step, two consensus measure methods are introduced to measure the consensus levels among the decision makers. (ii) Feedback adjustment.

Based on the standardized collective preference vector, the novel feedback adjustment rules, associated with different preference representation structures, are presented to help the decision makers modify their preference information. The details of the consensus process are introduced in Section 5.

Note 1: Herrera et al. [25] argued that two basic selection models may be considered. They are direct approach and indirect approach. The proposed framework is based on the direct approach, so this framework is called the direct consensus framework in this study. [6,7,30] The direct consensus framework is inspired by the MPDM model initiated by Chiclana et al. [6] and the corresponding consensus model presented in Herrera-Viedma et al. [30]. However, there are some differences between our proposal and the models presented in [6,7,30]. Specifically, the differences are shown from three aspects:

div.head: Differences between our proposal and the models presented in
div.p: (1) Process of selection.

The process of selection consists of three steps in models presented in [6,7,30], namely: (i) making the information uniform through transformation functions, in order to carry out the next step of aggregation. In [6,7,30], preference orderings, utility functions and multiplicative preference relations are transformed into fuzzy preference relations employing the corresponding transformation functions; (ii) aggregating all the uniformed individual preferences into a collective one via an aggregation operator. In [6,7,30], a collective fuzzy preference relation is obtained in this step; and (iii) ranking alternatives or selecting the best alternative (s) according to the quantifier-guided dominance degree (QGDD) and the quantifier-guided non-dominance degree (QGNDD).

In our direct consensus framework, the implementation of the process of selection contains two steps: (i) obtaining individual preference vectors by using the corresponding individual selection methods; and (ii) obtaining a collective preference vector by aggregating all the standardized individual preference vectors. In Section 6.2, an example (i.e., Example 1) is provided to illustrate these differences regarding the selection processes. (2) Process of consensus.

Compared with the model presented in Herrera-Viedma et al. [30], we proposed the novel feedback adjustment rules. The proposed feedback adjustment rules are associated with the individual preference representation structures, and consist of two steps: (i) the standardized collective preference vector is transformed into the preference information that is described by the preference representation structure used by the individual decision maker; and (ii) decision makers revised his/her preferences, according to the original individual preference information and the transformed collective preference information. The details of the feedback adjustment rules are introduced in Section 5.2. (3) Internal consistency and Pareto principle.

Our direct consensus framework can avoid internal inconsistency issue when using the transformation functions among different preference representation structures, and satisfy Pareto principle of social choice theory. The details of these two properties are introduced in Section 6.
The main notations used throughout this study are follows:

div.head: Selection process
div.p: This section proposed the selection process in the direct consensus framework. According to the formats of preference representation structures, four cases are considered.

div.head: Obtaining the individual preference vectors
div.p: Case A: e k 2 E U . In this case, the decision maker e k provides his/her preference information on X using the utility function U √∞k√û ¬º u

Case C: e k 2 E A . In this case, the decision maker e k provides his/her preference information on X by means of the multiplicative preference relation A √∞k√û ¬º a √∞k√û ij n√Çn . In AHP, two most commonly used prioritization methods are the eigenvalue method (EM), presented in [41], and the row geometric mean method (RGMM), presented in [12]. These two methods have similar effects [14,21]. However, the time complexity of the EM is greater than the RGMM. Therefore, we choose the RGMM as the selection method of multiplicative preference relations in this study. The RGMM can be described as model ( 6):

div.head: Consensus process
div.p: Classically, consensus is defined as the full and unanimous agreement of all the decision makers regarding all the possible alternatives. However, the complete agreement is not always necessary in real life. This has led to the use of ''soft'' consensus degree [33,34]. A lot of researchers [2,4,15,17,24,27,30,38,40,45,49] have investigated the consensus process for MPDM problems, based on the uses of ''soft'' consensus. Cabrerizo et al. [3] and Herrera-Viedma et al. [28] gave excellent surveys of consensus models. In Herrera-Viedma et al. [29], the more recent contributions can be found to analyze consensus from different approaches.
This section proposes the consensus process in the direct consensus framework. The proposed consensus process deals with a two-step procedure.

div.head: Consensus measure
div.p: In general, the computation of the consensus degree for MPDM problems is done by measuring the distance between individual preference values and collective preference values [10,15]. Particularly, Chiclana et al. [11] recently provided an interesting comparative study for the uses of different distance functions to measure consensus. By measuring the distance between individual preference values and collective preference values, we define the cardinal consensus degree (CCD) as Definition 5.
Definition 5. Let w (k‚ÅÑ) and w (c‚ÅÑ) be as earlier. The cardinal consensus degree for e k is defined by
div.formula: CCD√∞e k √û ¬º ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi 1 n X n i¬º1 √∞w √∞k√É√û i √Ä w √∞c√É√û i √û 2 r :√∞13√û
div.p: The cardinal consensus degree among all the decision makers is defined by
div.formula: CCDfe 1 ; . . . ; e m g ¬º 1 m X m k¬º1 CCD√∞e k √û:√∞14√û
div.p: If CCD{e 1 , . . ., e m } = 0, then all decision makers have full cardinal consensus with the collective opinion. Otherwise, the smaller CCD{e 1 , . . ., e m } value indicates the higher cardinal consensus level among {e 1 , . . ., e m }.
Let V √∞k√û ¬º v √∞k√û 1 ; v √∞k√û 2 ; . . . ; v √∞k√û n T

, where v √∞k√û i is the position of alternative x i in w (k‚ÅÑ) . For example, if w (k‚ÅÑ) = (0.2, 0.5, 0.3) T , then , where v √∞c√û i is the position of alternative x i in w (c‚ÅÑ) . Herrera-Viedma et al. [27,30] proposed the comparison approach of positions of alternatives between two preference vectors to measure the consensus degree.
Inspired by this idea, we define the ordinal consensus degree (OCD) as Definition 6.
Definition 6. The ordinal consensus degree for e k is defined by
div.formula: OCD√∞e k √û ¬º 1 n 2 X n i¬º1 v √∞k√û i √Ä v √∞c√û i :√∞15√û
div.p: The ordinal consensus degree among all the decision makers is defined by
div.formula: OCDfe 1 ; . . . ; e m g ¬º 1 m X m k¬º1 OCD√∞e k √û:√∞16√û
div.p: If OCD{e 1 , . . ., e m } = 0, then all decision makers have full ordinal consensus with the collective opinion. Otherwise, the smaller OCD{e 1 , . . ., e m } value indicates the higher ordinal consensus level among {e 1 , . . ., e m }.

Note 2: The origin of the CCD can be found in [10,11,15], and the origin of the OCD can be found in [27,30]. Usually, in many cases, the CCD and OCD values can be simultaneously decreased in our consensus reaching process, which will be shown in the illustrative example section. However, it will be interesting in any future research to compare the differences for the uses the CCD and the OCD, and design different feedback adjustment rules for the CCD and the OCD.

div.head: Feedback adjustment
div.p: Feedback adjustment aims at giving adjustment suggestions to help the decision makers improve the consensus level. A lot of feedback adjustment methods have been proposed [2,4,17,27,30,38,40]. In this study, we propose the novel feedback adjustment rules, which are associated with the individual preference representation structures, consist of two steps:

(i) Transforming the standardized collective preference vector w (c‚ÅÑ) into the preference information that is described by the preference representation structure used by the individual decision maker. For example, if the decision maker e k provided his/her preference information by the utility function, then the standardized collective preference vector w (c‚ÅÑ) is transformed into the preference information described by the utility function. In this way, the original preference information associated with the e k and the transformed collective preference information associated with the w (c‚ÅÑ) have a same preference representation structure. (ii) The decision makers revised his/her preferences, according to the original individual preference information and the transformed collective preference information.
According to the formats of preference representation structures, four cases for feedback adjustment are considered. ; i > j:

div.head: Desirable properties
div.p: In this section, we introduce two desirable properties of the proposed direct consensus framework.

div.head: Internal consistency and Pareto principle
div.p: Firstly, the concepts regarding the internal consistency and the Pareto principle of social choice theory have been provided as Definitions 7 and 8.

Definition 7 (Internal consistency [7,8]). The internal consistency refers to the ranking among alternatives derived from the transformed preference representation structure is the same one from the original preference representation structure. Definition 8 (Pareto principle [1,42]). Let x i and x j be two alternatives. If all decision makers prefer x i to x j , then the collective should be in favor of x i .
Next, we propose the desirable properties of the direct consensus framework as Proposition 1, 2.
Proposition 1. The direct consensus framework can avoid internal inconsistency issue.

Proof. In the direct consensus framework, there only exists the transformation between the preference vectors and the standardized preference vectors. While, since w Proposition 2 guarantees that the direct consensus framework satisfies the Pareto principle of social choice theory.

(1) The selection process presented in [6,7,30].

Using the fuzzy majority criterion with the fuzzy linguistic quantifier ''most'' (i.e., the OWA operator with weighting (0.4,0.6) T ), w (1‚ÅÑ) and w (2‚ÅÑ) are aggregated into a collective preference vector w (c) : w √∞c√û ¬º √∞0:2715; 0:2608; 0:1293; 0:1143; 0:0918; 0:0814√û T :

Observing the values of w (1) and w (2) , we find that both decision makers consider that x 1 is the best alternative. From w (c) , we find that the best alternative is also x 1 , which satisfies Pareto principle.
Next, Example 2 is given to show that the transformation function between multiplicative preference relations and fuzzy preference relations, presented in [7], does not satisfy internal consistency.
Example 2. Let X = {x 1 , . . ., x 6 } be six alternatives. Assume that decision maker e 3 provides his/her preference information using a multiplicative preference relation A √∞3√û ¬º a :
Based on Eq. ( 7), the preference vector is derived from

From the values of w (3) , we find that alternative x 1 is better than x 2 . However, alternative x 2 is better than x 1 according to QGGD (3) , which contradicts the internal consistency.

In our proposal, there only exists the transformation between the preference vectors and the standardized preference vectors. div.head: Illustrative example
div.p: In order to demonstrate the proposed direct consensus framework, let us consider the example presented in Herrera-Viedma et al. [30]. In this example, there are a set of eight decision makers E = {e 1 , e 2 , . . ., e 8 } and a set of six alternatives X = {x 1 , . . ., x 6 }. The decision makers e 1 and e 2 provide their opinions using the utility functions U (1) and U (2) . The decision makers e 3 and e 4 provide their opinions using the preference orderings O (3) and O (4) . The decision makers e 5 and e 6 provide their opinions using the multiplicative preference relations A (5) and A (6) . And, the decision makers e 7 and e 8 provide their opinions using the fuzzy preference relations P (7) and P (8) . These preferences are as follows:

U √∞1√û ¬º√∞0:3; 0:2; 0:8; 0:6; 0:4; 0:1√û T ; U √∞2√û ¬º√∞0:3; 0:9; 0:4; 0:2; 0:7; 0:5√û The implementation of the selection process, presented in the direct consensus framework, deals with a two-step procedure: obtaining individual preference vectors and obtaining a collective preference vector.
(1) Obtaining individual preference vectors.

According to the formats of preference representation structures, the individual preference vectors are respectively derived. Since e 1 , e 2 2 E U , using Eq. ( 4) obtains w (1) and w (2) from U (1) and U (2) , i.e., w (1) = (0.3, 0.2, 0.8, 0.6, 0.4, 0.1) T and w (2) = (0.3, 0.9, 0.4, 0.2, 0.7, 0.5) T . Since e 3 , e 4 2 E O , using Eq. ( 5) obtains w (3) and w (4) from O (3) and O (4) , i.e., w (3) = (0.8, 1, 0.6, 0, 0.4, 0.2) T and w (4) = (1, 0.6, 0.4, 0.8, 0, 0.2) T . Since e 5 , e 6 2 E A , using Eq. ( 7) obtains w (5) and w (6) from A (5) and A (6) , i.e., w (5) = (0.1762, 0.1512, 0.4654, 0.0928, 0.0832, 0.0312) T and w (6) = (0.0668, 0.2879, 0.308, 0.1666, 0.0772, 0.0935) T . Since e 7 , e 8 2 E P , according to Eq. ( 8), using the fuzzy quantifier ''as many as possible'' (i.e., the OWA operator with the weighting (0, 0, 0, 1/3, 1/3, 1/3) T ) obtains the OGDD values from P (7) and P (8) . Then, using Eq. ( 9) obtains w (7) and w (8) :

(2) Obtaining a collective preference vector. Firstly, the individual preference vector Then, according to Eq. ( 11), using the fuzzy quantifier ''most'' (i.e., the OWA operator with the weighting vector (0, 0, 0.15, 0.25, 0.25, 0.25, 0.1, 0) T ) obtains a collective preference vector, i.e., w (c) : w √∞c√û ¬º √∞0:1663; 0:2105; 0:2098; 0:1173; 0:1108; 0:0785√û T :

div.head: Consensus process
div.p: The implementation of the consensus process, presented in the direct consensus framework, deals with a two-step procedure: consensus measure and feedback adjustment. Here, we demonstrate how to improve the cardinal and ordinal consensus levels among the decision makers.

Applying Eqs. ( 14) and ( 16) obtains the cardinal and ordinal consensus degrees among the decision makers, CCD{e 1 , . . ., e 8 } = 0.0767 and OCD{e 1 , . . ., e 8 } = 0.2153, respectively. Then, the proposed feedback adjustment rules are used to improve consensus levels among decision makers. According to the formats of preference representation structures, different feedback adjustment rules are considered.

Since e 1 , e 2 2 E U , using Eq. ( 17) transforms w (c‚ÅÑ) into the preference information described by the utility functions, associated with e 1 and e 2 . They are U √∞c;1√û ¬º √∞0:4469; 0:5657; 0:5638; 0:3154; 0:2976; 0:2107√û T ; U √∞c;2√û ¬º √∞0:5586; 0:7071; 0:7047; 0:3942; 0:3720; 0:2634√û T : 1) and SUG (2) are as follows:
Again, using the proposed selection process derives a standardized collective preference vector, w √∞c√É√û ¬º √∞0:2162; 0:2339; 0:2011; 0:1403; 0:1442; 0:0643√û T :

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this study, we investigate the MPDM problem with different preference representation structures (preference orderings, utility functions, multiplicative preference relations and fuzzy preference relations). The main points presented are as follows:

(1) Inspired by the MPDM model initiated by Chiclana et al. [6] and the corresponding consensus model presented in Herrera-Viedma et al. [30], and also inspired by the direct approach presented in Herrera et al. [25], we propose a direct consensus framework for MPDM problems with different preference representation structures. (2) We present the selection process in the direct consensus framework. In the proposed selection process, the individual selection methods, associated with different preference representation structures, are used to obtain individual preference vectors of alternatives. Then, the standardized individual preference vectors are aggregated into a collective preference vector. (3) We propose the consensus process in the direct consensus framework. In the proposed consensus process, based on the collective preference vector, the novel feedback adjustment rules, associated with different preference representation structures, are presented to help the decision makers reach consensus. (4) We show that the proposed framework can avoid the internal inconsistency issue, and also satisfy the Pareto principle of social choice theory.

Moreover, Fan et al. [18,19], Ma et al. [36], and Fan and Zhang [20] initiated several optimization-based models to integrate different preference representation structures. We argue that it will be interesting in any future research to see if a comparative study of different MPDM models with different preference representation structures is proposed.
